Authors:
Ya Shuang Guo, Qing Bai, min fu, Meng-Meng Yang, Xianhong
Wang, Yamin Du, Wen-Xing Xu, Guo-Ping Wang
Title:
High species diversity in Diaporthe associated with pear
shoot canker in China
Abstract:
Diaporthe (anamorph Phomopsis) fungi are important
endophytes, saprobes and pathogens, infecting a wide range of plants,
and related to many important crop diseases. However, the species
occurring on pear remain largely unresolved. In this study, a total of
453 Diaporthe isolates were isolated from the branches of Pyrus plants
(including P. pyrifolia, P. bretschneideri, P. ussuriensis and P.
communis) showing shoot canker symptoms collected from 12 provinces in
China. Phylogenetic analyses based on five loci (ITS, TEF, CAL, HIS, and
TUB) coupled with morphology of 113 representative isolates revealed
that 19 Diaporthe species were isolated, with 13 known species
(including D. eres, D. hongkongensis, D. sojae, D. unshiuensis, D.
fusicola, D. velutina, D. ganjae, D. caryae, D. padina, D.
citrichinensis, D. taoicola, D. cercidis and D. pescicola) and six novel
species described here as D. acriae, D. chongqingensis, D. fulvicola, D.
parvusis, D. spinamia and D. zaobaisum. It is worth to note that all
these species are responsible for the pear shoot canker identified by
following the KochÂ’s postulates, but show a highly varied virulence.
Moreover, these species have a high diversity, plasticity, and
prevalence closely related to the geographical location and pear species
in China. This is the first report of these 18 Diaporthe species besides
D. eres infecting pear.
